tit.j: 京都大学フィールド科学教育研究センター森林ステーション芦生研究林
tit.e: Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station
Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station
Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station

sen.j: 京都大学フィールド科学教育研究センター森林ステーション芦生研究林（きょうとだいがくふぃーるどかがくきょういくけんきゅうせんたーしんりんすてーしょんあしうけんきゅうりん、略称：京都大学芦生研究林）は、京都府南丹市美山町 (京都府)にある京都大学の研究施設である。
sen.e: Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station (abbreviated to "Ashiu Forest Research Station, Kyoto University") is a research facility of Kyoto University, located in Miyama-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture (Kyoto Prefecture).

Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station (abbreviated to "Ashiu Forest Research Station, Kyoto University") is a research facility of Kyoto University, located in Miyama-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture (Kyoto Prefecture).

Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station (abbreviated to "Ashiu Forest Research Station, Kyoto University") is a research facility of Kyoto University, located in Miyama-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture (Kyoto Prefecture).

sen.j: 1921年に当時の京都帝国大学初の国内演習林として北桑田郡知井村九ヶ字共有林約4,200haに地上権を設定し、同地を芦生演習林と称したことから始まった。
sen.e: Its origin is as follows: In 1921, superficies was settled for approx. 4,200 ha of a common forest in Kukeji of Chii Village, Kitakuwada County, as Kyoto Imperial University's first domestic forest for field practice and the area was called the Ashiu forest for field practice.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処九ヶ字： 読み方確認されておりません。
sen.e: Origin: In 1921, superficies was settled for approx. 4,200 ha of a common forest in Kukeji of Chii Village, Kitakuwada County, as Kyoto Imperial University's first domestic forest for field practice and the area was called the Ashiu forest for field practice.
sen.cmt: Robert: Translation doesn't make any sense
sen.e: Origin: In 1921, Kyoto Imperial University acquired the surface rights to approx. 4,200 ha of a jointly owned forest in Kukeji of Chii Village, Kitakuwada County; this area became the university's first domestic research forest and was given the name the "Ashiu Research Forest."
sen.cmt: superficies→surface rights, 九ヶ字： 読み方確認されておりません。I've had to rewrite this quite a bit.

sen.j: その後1923年の農学部設置に伴い学生や研究者向けの学術研究及び実地研究の場として活用された。
sen.e: Then, after the agriculture department was established, the forest was effectively used for academic research and field work by researchers and students.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Following this, the agriculture department was established, and the forest was used for academic research and field work by researchers and students.
Following this, the agriculture department was established, and the forest was used for academic research and field work by researchers and students.

sen.j: ほか、大学の財産形成の場として、伐採に伴う用材収入や製炭事業などでの収入が用いられた。
sen.e: In addition, the income from selling the woods that were cut in the forest and from charcoal-making business was used for creating the wealth of the university.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, the income from selling wood obtained from cutting down trees in the forest, and from charcoal-making business was used to create income for the university.
In addition, the income from selling wood obtained from cutting down trees in the forest, and from charcoal-making business was used to create income for the university.

sen.j: 近畿地方に残る数少ない大規模天然林である。
sen.e: It is one of a few natural forests still remaining in the Kinki region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is one of the few natural forests still remaining in the Kinki region.
It is one of the few large scale natural forests still remaining in the Kinki region.
sen.cmt: ”大規模天然林”ということで、the few large scale natural forestと修正しました。

sen.j: 中には原生林もあることから、芦生原生林や芦生の森とも呼ばれることがある。
sen.e: Because including virgin forests, it is sometimes called the Ashiu virgin forest or the Ashiu woods.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because including virgin forests, it is sometimes called the Ashiu virgin forest or the Ashiu woods.
sen.cmt: Robert: Translation doesn't make any sense
sen.e: Because it includes some virgin forests in, it is sometimes called the Ashiu virgin forest or the Ashiu woods.
sen.cmt: 原文から考えて修正しました。

sen.j: ほか、現在でも旧称の芦生演習林で広く通じている。
sen.e: Furthermore, even today, the old name of the Ashiu forest for field practice is also used commonly.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, even today, the old name of Ashiu forest for field practice is still commonly used.
Also, even today, the old name of Ashiu forest for field practice is still commonly used.

sen.j: この項では、基本として「研究林」の呼称を使うが、歴史的な記述を中心に「演習林」の呼称も併用する。
sen.e: In the following descriptions, "the forest for research" is basically used for referring to it, but "the forest for field practice" is also used sometimes centered on historical descriptions.
In the following descriptions, "research forest" is basically used to refer to this particular forest, but "field practice forest" is also sometimes used when referring to historical descriptions.
In the following descriptions, "research forest" is basically used to refer to this particular forest, but "field practice forest" is also used when referring to historical descriptions.
sen.cmt: 文脈からしてsometimesは不要としました。

sen.j: 当研究林の所在地は、京都市内中心部から北北東に約35km離れた福井県・滋賀県両県と接する京都府北東部の由良川源流域である。
sen.e: This research forest is located around the riverhead of the Yura-gawa river in the north-east part of Kyoto Prefecture, where is approx. 35 km apart in the north-north east from the central part of Kyoto City and borders Fukui and Shiga Prefectures.

This research forest is located around the riverhead of the Yura-gawa river in the north-east part of Kyoto Prefecture, that is approx. 35 km north-north east from the central part of Kyoto City and borders Fukui and Shiga Prefectures.

This research forest is located around the headwaters of the Yura-gawa River in the north-east part of Kyoto Prefecture, that is approx. 35 km north-north east from the central part of Kyoto City and borders Fukui and Shiga Prefectures.
sen.cmt: riverhead→headwatersと修正しました。 Yura-gawa river→Yura-gawa Riverと修正しました。

sen.j: 南部及び南東部は京都市左京区の広河原 (京都市)及び久多地区に、北東部は滋賀県高島市の朽木村に、北部は福井県おおい町の旧名田庄村にそれぞれ接している。
sen.e: Its southern and southeastern areas border the Hirogawara (in Kyoto City) area and Kuta area in Sakyo Ward of Kyoto City, the northeastern area does Kutsuki-mura, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture, and the northern area does the former Natasho Village in Ooi Town, Fukui Prefecture.

Its southern and southeastern areas border the Hirogawara (in Kyoto City) area and Kuta area in Sakyo Ward of Kyoto City, the northeastern area borders Kutsuki-mura, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture, and the northern area borders the former Natasho Village in Ooi Town, Fukui Prefecture.

Its southern and southeastern areas border the Hirogawara (in Kyoto City) area and Kuta area in Sakyo Ward of Kyoto City, the northeastern area borders Kutsuki-mura, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture, and the northern area borders the former Natasho-mura in Oi-cho, Fukui Prefecture.
sen.cmt: Natasho Village→Natasho-mura,Ooi Town→Oi-choに修正しました。

sen.j: 地形は、当研究林が丹波高地東端部にあることから標高が高い。
sen.e: Since this forest for research is located in the east-end area of the Tanba highland, its altitudes are high.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The research forest is located in a high altitude area due to its being in the east-end area of the Tanba highland.
Topographically, the altitude is high since the research forest is located in the east-end area of the Tanba highland.
sen.cmt: 原文から考えて修正しました。

sen.j: 三国岳(959m)を最高地点に、傘峠 (935m)や小野村割岳(931.7m)など標高900m以上の地点が南部から東部にかけて点在し、標高600-800mの部分が全体の約2/3を占める。
sen.e: Many points higher than 900 m, for examples, the peak of Mikuni-dake Mountain at the highest altitude of 959 m, the Karakasa Pass at an altitude of 935 m and the peak of Mt. Onomurawaridake at an altitude of 931.7 m, exist in the southern to eastern areas, with the area at altitudes of 600 m to 800 m occupying approx. 2/3 of the entire forest area.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Locations higher than 900 m, for examples, the peak of Mikuni-dake Mountain at the highest altitude of 959 m, the Karakasa Pass at an altitude of 935 m and the peak of Mt. Onomurawaridake at an altitude of 931.7 m, exist in the southern to eastern areas, with the area at altitudes of 600 m to 800 m occupying approx. 2/3 of the entire forest area.

There are points dotted around with altitude over 900m, such as Mikuni-dake Mountain (959m) the highest point, then Karakasa Pass (935m), and Mt. Onomurawaridake (931.7m) located in its southern to eastern part, about two thirds of the entire area is at an altitude of between 600m to 800m.
sen.cmt: 原文から考えて全体的に修正しました。

sen.j: 標高は西に向かって低くなり、研究林事務所では356m、最低地点では355mである。
sen.e: The altitudes become lower towards west, for example, 356 m at the administration building in the forest for researche, with the lowest altitude point of 355 m.
The altitude is lower in the west, for example, 356 m at research forest administration building, with the lowest altitude being 355 m.
The altitude is lower in the west, for example, 356 m at research forest administration building, with the lowest altitude being 355 m.
sen.cmt: at と research の間のスペースを修正しました。

sen.j: また、林内を由良川の源流がU字形に流れ、谷筋には大小の河谷が由良川源流に注ぎ込んでいる。
sen.e: The initial portion of the Yura-gawa river flows in the shape of U within the forest, and little or big streams along valleys flow into the riverhead of the Yura-gawa river.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The initial portion of the Yura-gawa river flows in the shape of a U within the forest, and little or big streams along the valleys flow into the river head of the Yura-gawa river.
The initial portion of the Yura-gawa River flows in the shape of a U within the forest, and little or big streams along the valleys flow into the headwaters of the Yura-gawa River.
sen.cmt: Yura-gawa river→Yura-gawa River,river head→headwatersと修正しました。

sen.j: 全体的には丹波高地の各所で見られる地形輪廻状の地形であるが、斜面部の傾斜は30～40度と比較的急峻である。
sen.e: As a whole, the land takes the shapes that land takes in the natural cycle, as seen in various areas in the Tanba highland, and the inclination of the slopes are rather precipitous at 30 to 40 degrees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As a whole, the land takes the shape that land takes in its natural cycle, as seen in various areas in the Tanba highland, and the inclination of the slopes are rather steep at 30 to 40 degrees.
As a whole, the land is shaped by its cycle of erosion, as seen in various areas in the Tanba highland; however, the inclination of the slopes are rather steep at 30 to 40 degrees.
sen.cmt: ”地形輪廻”を cycle of erosionとし、原文から見て全体的に修正しました。

sen.j: 地質は丹波帯と呼ばれる中・古生層に属する砂岩や泥岩（頁岩）の基盤岩に東西に延びるチャート (岩石)層を挟む、堆積岩で形成されたものである。
sen.e: The land is formed by sedimentary rock on the chert layer that extends in the east-west direction on the base rock of the sand stone and mudstone (shale) belonging to the Mesozoic/Paleozoic layer called the Tanba belt.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The land is formed from sedimentary rock on the chert layer that extends in the east-west direction on the base rock of the sand stone and mudstone (shale) belonging to the Mesozoic/Paleozoic layer called the Tanba belt.

The geographical feature is formed from sedimentary rock on the chert layer that extends in the east-west direction on the base rock of the sand stone and mudstone (shale) belonging to the Mesozoic/Paleozoic layer called the Tanba belt.
sen.cmt: 地質：geological feature としました。

sen.j: チャートが卓越する場所では急崖や滝が形成されている。
sen.e: Precipitous cliffs or falls are formed in the areas where chert dominates
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Precipitous cliffs or falls are formed in areas where chert dominates
Precipitous cliffs or falls are formed in areas where chert dominates.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを挿入しました。

sen.j: 土質は大部分が褐色森林土であるが、標高800m以上の稜線部には局所的にポドゾル土壌が認められる。
sen.e: Most of the soil is brown forest soil, but Podzol is also found locally in ridges higher than an altitude of 800 m.
Most of the soil is brown forest soil, but Podzol is also found locally in ridges higher than an altitude of 800 m.
Most of the soil is brown forest soil, but Podzol is also found locally in ridges higher than an altitude of 800 m.

sen.j: 当研究林全体が日本海側気候と太平洋岸気候の移行帯に属しており、年間を通じて降水量が多い。
sen.e: This forest for research entirely belongs to the transitionary area between the climate on the Japan Sea side and that of the Pacific Ocean coast side, and lots of rain falls there throughout the year.
This research forest belongs entirely to the transitionary area between the climate on the Japan Sea side and that of the Pacific coast side, with lots of rain falls throughout the year.
This research forest belongs entirely to the transitional area between the climate on the Japan Sea side and that of the Pacific coast side, with lots of rain falls throughout the year.

sen.j: 事務所構内の年平均気温は11.7℃、降水量は2,353mmで、京都市内に比べると平均気温で3-4℃低く、降水量は約1.6倍である。
sen.e: The yearly average of air temperature in the premises of the administration building is 11.7℃, 3 to 4 degrees lower than that in the central area of Kyoto City, and the yearly average of rain fall amount there is 2,353 mm, approx. 1.6 times that in the central area of Kyoto City.

The yearly air temperature average in the administration building is 11.7℃, which is 3 to 4 degrees lower than the central area of Kyoto City, and the yearly average of rain fall amount there is 2,353 mm, approx. 1.6 times that of the central area of Kyoto City.

The yearly air temperature average in the administration building is 11.7℃, which is 3 to 4 degrees lower than the central area of Kyoto City, and the yearly average of rain fall amount there is 2,353 mm, approx. 1.6 times that of the central area of Kyoto City.

sen.j: 標高が事務所構内より約300m上昇する東部の長治谷(標高640m)では、事務所構内に比べて年平均気温が約2℃低く、降水量も400-600mm程度多くなる。
sen.e: At Chojidani (at an altitude of 640 m) in the eastern part, located approx. 300 m higher in the altitude than the premises of the administration building, the yearly average of air temperature is approx. two degrees lower than that in the premises of the administration building, and the yearly average of rain fall amount there is around 400 mm to 600 mm more than that in the premises of the administration building.

At Chojidani (at an altitude of 640 m) in the eastern part, located approx. 300 m higher in the altitude than the premises of the administration building, the yearly air temperature average is approx. two degrees lower than average for the administration building, and the yearly average of rain fall is around 400 mm to 600 mm more than the average for the administration building.

At Chojidani (at an altitude of 640 m) in the eastern part, located approx. 300 m higher in the altitude than the premises of the administration building, the yearly air temperature average is approx. two degrees lower than the average for the administration building, and the yearly average of rain fall is around 400 mm to 600 mm more than the average for the administration building.
sen.cmt: average の前にtheを挿入しました。

sen.j: また、豪雪地帯としても知られており、事務所構内の積雪深は1m前後、長治谷では2mを超える。
sen.e: The place is also known as a heavy snowfall area, with the snow in the premises of the administration building being accumulated in around 1 meter and that at Chojidani exceeding two meters.
The place is also known for heavy snowfall, with approximately 1 meter of snow accumulating in the administration building area and more than 2 meters around Chojidani.
The place is also known for heavy snowfall, with approximately 1 meter of snow accumulating in the administration building area and more than 2 meters around Chojidani.

sen.j: その年の気候にもよるが、初雪は11月に降り、4月に入っても雪が舞うこともある。
sen.e: Although being dependent on the climate in the year, the first snow of the season falls in November and snow sometimes falls even in April.
Although it changes depending on the climate for the year, the first snow of the season generally falls in November and can continue to fall until as late as April.
Although it changes depending on the climate for the year, the first snow of the season generally falls in November and can continue to fall until as late as April.

sen.j: 12月以降に降った雪は根雪となることが多く、長治谷をはじめ林内の多くの地域が12月から4月初めまで根雪に閉ざされてしまう。
sen.e: The snow fallen in December or later mostly remains without being melt, and many areas of the forest, including Chojidani, remain covered wit such snow from December to the early days of April.
The snowfall from December and later mostly remains without melting, and many areas of the forest, including Chojidani, remain covered in snow from December to early April.
The snowfall from December and later mostly remains without melting, and many areas of the forest, including Chojidani, remain covered in snow from December to early April.

sen.j: 前述のように当研究林が日本海側気候と太平洋岸気候の移行帯に位置していることから、植生区分の上でも暖温帯林と冷温帯林の移行帯に属し、植物の種類が多い。
sen.e: Since, as described above, this forest for research belongs to the transitionary area between the climate on the Japan Sea side an that of the Pacific Ocean coast side, the flora there also belongs to the transitionary area between the warm-temperate forest and the cool-temperate forest, with plants of various species growing there.

Since, as described above, this research forest belongs to the transitionary area between the climate on the Japan Sea side and that of the Pacific coast side, the flora there also belongs to the transitionary area between the warm-temperate forest and the cool-temperate forest, which houses various species of plants.

Since, as described above, this research forest belongs to the transitional area between the climate on the Japan Sea side and that of the Pacific coast side, the flora there also belongs to the transitional area between the warm-temperate forest and the cool-temperate forest, which houses various species of plants.

sen.j: 当研究林内で確認されている種数は、木が243種、草本が532種、シダ植物が85種を数える。
sen.e: Within this forest for research, trees of 243 species, grass plants of 532 species and fern-related plants of 85 species have been found.
Within this research forest, 243 species of trees, 532 species of grass, and 85 species of fern-related plants have been found.
Within this research forest, 243 species of trees, 532 species of grass, and 85 species of fern-related plants have been found.

sen.j: その中には、下枝が雪の重みで接地することで茎伏せし、やがて一個体として独立して増殖する、多雪地帯に特有の伏条更新を行うことで知られるアシウスギやアシウテンナンショウのように「芦生」の地名を冠した学術上貴重な植物が含まれている。
sen.e: They include academically important plants whose names include the geographic name of "Ashiu," such as Ashiu-sugi (Cryptomeria japonica var. radicans) and Ashiu-tennansho (Arisaema robustum var. ovale) that produce their offspring in the following way specific to heavy snow areas: When snow accumulates on their lower branches, they come to touch the ground due to the snow weight, and independent plants grow from the ground.

They include academically important plants whose names include the geographical name of "Ashiu," such as Ashiu-sugi (Cryptomeria japonica var. radicans) and Ashiu-tennansho (Arisaema robustum var. ovale) that produce their offspring in the following way specific to areas with heavy snowfall: When snow accumulates on their lower branches, they come to touch the ground due to the weight of the snow, causing this part to become independent and grow on its own from the ground.

They include academically important plants whose names include the geographical name of "Ashiu," such as Ashiu-sugi (Cryptomeria japonica var. radicans) and Ashiu-tennansho (Arisaema robustum var. ovale) that produce their offspring in the following way specific to areas with heavy snowfall: When snow accumulates on their lower branches, they come to touch the ground due to the weight of the snow, causing this part to become independent and grow on its own from the ground.

sen.j: また、多雪地帯に特有のエゾユズリハ、ヒメアオキ、ヒメモチ、ハイイヌガヤなどの植物が自生しているほか、氷河期の遺存種であるニッコウキスゲやリュウキンカも生育している。
sen.e: Plants, such as Daphniphyllim macropodum var. humile, Aucuba japonica var. borealis, Ilex leucoclada, and Cephalotaxus harringtonia var. nana, specific to heavy snow areas grow naturally.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Plants, such as Daphniphyllim macropodum var. humile, Aucuba japonica var. borealis, Ilex leucoclada, and Cephalotaxus harringtonia var. nana, which are specific to heavy snow areas grow here naturally.

Plants, such as Daphniphyllim macropodum var. humile, Aucuba japonica var. borealis, Ilex leucoclada, and Cephalotaxus harringtonia var. nana, which are specific to heavy snow areas grow here naturally.

sen.j: そのほか、氷河期の遺存種であるニッコウキスゲやリュウキンカも生育している。
sen.e: In addition, Hemerocallis middendorffii var. esculenta and Caltha palustris var. nipponica, all of which are species remaining from the glacial age, also grow there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, Hemerocallis middendorffii var. esculenta and Caltha palustris var. nipponica, all of which are species remaining from the ice age, also grow here.
In addition, Hemerocallis middendorffii var. esculenta and Caltha palustris var. nipponica, all of which are species remaining from the ice age, also grow here.

sen.j: この他、年間降水量が多いことから、ナメコやヒラタケ、ツキヨタケをはじめ多様なキノコが繁殖している。
sen.e: Furthermore, since much rain falls in a year, a variety of mushrooms, including nameko mushroom, oyster mushroom and Lampteromyces japonicus, grow there.
Furthermore, due to the heavy rainfall throughout the year, a variety of mushrooms, including nameko mushroom, oyster mushroom and Lampteromyces japonicus, grow here.
Furthermore, due to the heavy rainfall throughout the year, a variety of mushrooms, including nameko mushroom, oyster mushroom and Lampteromyces japonicus, grow here.

sen.j: 天然林では標高600m以下ではコナラやウラジロガシ、ソヨゴといった暖温帯林構成種が見られる。
sen.e: In the natural forest, plants in warm-temperate forests, such as quercus serrata, Quercus salicina and Ilexpedunnculosa, are found in the areas lower than an altitude of 600 m.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the natural forest, plants in warm-temperate forests, such as quercus serrata, Quercus salicina and Ilexpedunnculosa, are found in areas lower than 600 m above sea level.
In the natural forest, plants in warm-temperate forests, such as konara oak, Quercus salicina and Ilexpedunnculosa, are found in areas lower than 600 m above sea level.

sen.j: それ以上の標高になるとブナ、ミズナラなどを主体とした冷温帯林構成種が見られる。
sen.e: In the areas higher than that, plants in cool-temperate forests, including Fagus crenata and Quercus mongoloca var. grosseseratta, are found.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In areas higher than this, plants in cool-temperate forests, including Fagus crenata and Quercus mongoloca var. grosseseratta, are found.
In areas higher than this, plants in cool-temperate forests, including beech and Mongolian oak, are found.
sen.cmt: Fagus crenata→beech,Quercus mongoloca var. grosseseratta→Mongolian oak

sen.j: しかし、その境界は不明瞭である。
sen.e: However, the boundary between these areas is unclear.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the boundary between these areas is unclear.
However, the boundary between these areas is unclear.

sen.j: また、斜面に対応して樹木が分布しており、斜面上部ではアシウスギの分布密度が高く、中腹ではブナを主としてミズナラなどが優先し、沢筋ではトチノキやサワグルミなどが多く分布する。
sen.e: On the slopes, various types of trees grow corresponding to the height as in the following: In the upper area, Ashiu-sugi grow densely, in the middle area, Fagus crenata grow primarily, followed by Quercus mongoloca var. grosseseratta, and in the valleys, Aesculus turbinata and Pterocarya rhoifolia grow mostly.

On the slopes, various types of trees grow corresponding to the height as in the following: The upper area is desnsely packed with Ashiu-sugi, while the middle area is primarily populated by Fagus crenata followed by Quercus mongoloca var. grosseseratta, and Aesculus turbinata and Pterocarya rhoifolia grow mostly in the valleys,

On the slopes, various types of trees grow corresponding to the height as in the following: The upper area is densely packed with Ashiu-sugi, while the middle area is primarily populated by beech followed by Mongolian oak, and Japanese horse chestnut and Japanese wing nut grow mostly in the valleys,
sen.cmt: desnsely→densely,Fagus crenata→beech,Quercus mongoloca var. grosseseratta→Mongolian oak,Aesculus turbinata→ Japanese horse chestnut,Pterocarya rhoifolia→ Japanese wing nut

sen.j: このような植生の多様性から、植物学者で東京大学教授の中井猛之進が『植物ヲ学ブモノハ一度ハ京大ノ芦生演習林ヲ見ルベシ』と研究誌に書いたことでも知られている。
sen.e: It is known that, because of its diversity in the flora, Takenoshin NAKAI, a botanist and professor at Tokyo University, wrote in a research journal that "Persons studying flora should visit the Ashiu forest for field practice of Kyoto University."

It is known that, because of its diversity in flora, Takenoshin NAKAI, a botanist and professor at Tokyo University, wrote in a research journal that "Persons studying flora should visit the Ashiu forest for field practice of Kyoto University."
sen.cmt: Robert: Translation doesn't make sense ""Persons studying flora should visit the Ashiu forest for field practice of Kyoto University."
sen.e: It is known that,Takenoshin NAKAI, a botanist and professor at Tokyo University wrote in a research journal as "People studying botany should visit the Ashiu forest for field practice of Kyoto University" because of its diversity in flora.
sen.cmt: 植物学: botany としました。

sen.j: 当研究林は後述のように古くから利用されてきた森林である。
sen.e: This forest for research has been used from a long time ago, as described later.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This research forest has been used for a long time, as described later.
This research forest has been used for a long time, as described later.

sen.j: 木材の伐採のほか、野田畑周辺では茅場として使用するために火入れが行われていた。
sen.e: For example, in addition to the cutting of woods, some areas around those used for arable land were burnt to make plants for thatch be grown.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For example, in addition to cutting down trees for wood, some surrounding areas used as arable land were burnt down to grow plants used for thatch.
In addition to cutting down trees for wood, around Nodabata, clearings were burnt off to be used as hayfields.
sen.cmt: For example を削除しました。茅場: hayfield として修正しました。

sen.j: 演習林の開設後は、戦前は森林軌道が開通した由良川源流域を中心に伐採が行われ、伐採跡にはスギの造林が行われた。
sen.e: After the forest for field practice was established, woods were cut in the pre-war days, centered around the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa river where a forest tramroad started its operation, and Japanese cedar tress were planted in the areas where woods had been cut.

After the field practice forest was established, trees were cut down during pre-war days, centered around the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa river where a forest tramroad was operated, and Japanese cedar tress were planted in the areas where trees had been cut down.

After the field practice forest was established, trees were cut down mainly around the headwaters of the Yura-gawa River, where a forest tramline was opened before the war, then Japanese cedar trees were planted at the site afterwards.
sen.cmt: tramroad→tramline原文から考えて修正しました。

sen.j: 戦後は林道の開設に伴って大規模伐採を実施、1950年代後半から1960年代中期にかけてピークを迎えた。
sen.e: After the war, a forest road was laid out, and woods were cut on a large scale, with its cutting-activity peak in the era from around the latter half of 1950s to the middle of 1960s.
After the war, a forest road was laid out, and trees were cut down on a large scale, which peaked around the latter half of 1950s to the middle of 1960s.
After the war, trees were cut down on a large scale as forest roads were laid out, which reached its peak around the latter half of 1950s to the middle of 1960s.
sen.cmt: 原文から考えて修正しました。a forest road was→forest roads were

sen.j: その後伐採規模は縮小し、1990年代以降はほとんど伐採されることがなくなった。
sen.e: After that, the amount of woods cut diminished, and almost no wood has been cut since 1990s.
After that, the amount of tree cutting diminished, and almost no trees have been cut since the 1990s.
After that, the amount of tree cutting diminished, and almost no trees have been cut since the 1990s.

sen.j: 現在、当研究林の総面積4,200haの約半分に当たる2,150haは少なくとも開設後は手の入っていない天然林で、この中には森林の成立以降人為的な力の加わっていないと考えられる原生林がある。
sen.e: At present, the natural forest, which has been touched by no human being since the opening of the forest for field practice, occupies 2,150 ha, approx, half of the total area of 4,2000 ha of this forest for research, and virgin forests, which are considered not having been touched by any human being since the forest had been formed, exist there.

At present, the natural forest, which has not been touched by any human since the opening of the field practice forest, occupies 2,150 ha, approx, half of the total area of 42,000 ha of this research forest, and virgin forests, which are considered not to have ever been touched by humans since the forest was formed, exist here.

Currently, the natural forest, which has not been touched at least since the the field practice forest opened covers 2,150 ha, approx, half of the total area of 4,200 ha of this research forest, and there are virgin forests within it that are considered to be untouched by humans ever since the forest was formed.
sen.cmt: 42,000→4,200,原文から考えて修正しました。

sen.j: 天然林の伐採跡地のうち、大半の面積を占める約1,800haは伐採後再生した天然林（二次林）で、スギを主体とした人工造林の面積は約250haである。
sen.e: Of the former natural forest where woods were cut, approx. 1,800 ha, most of such areas, has become the natural forest (secondary forest) regenerated after the wood-cutting, and approx. 250 ha became artificially regenerated forests where Japanese cedar tress have been planted.

Of the former natural forest where trees were cut down, approx. 1,800 ha, has become natural forest (secondary forest) that regenerated after the logging, and approx. 250 ha became artificially regenerated forests where Japanese cedar tress were planted.

Of the former natural forest where trees were cut down, approx. 1,800 ha which covers its majority has become a natural forest (secondary forest) that regrew after the logging, and the artificial afforestation which is mostly Japanese ceder trees covers approx. 250 ha.
sen.cmt: 再生:regrow, 人工造林:artificial afforestation とし、全体を修正しました。

sen.j: 二次林にはミズメ、シデやクロモジなどが多い。
sen.e: Japanese Cherry Birch, hornbeam and spice bush grow mostly in the secondary forests.
Japanese Cherry Birch, hornbeam and spice bush grow mostly in the secondary forests.
Japanese Cherry Birch, hornbeam and spice bush grow mostly in the secondary forests.

sen.j: 植生同様当研究林内には多くの生物が生息している。
sen.e: As the flora is, the fauna in this forest for research is diverse as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The fauna in this research forest is as diverse as the flora.
The fauna in this research forest is as diverse as the flora.

sen.j: 哺乳類ではツキノワグマやニホンカモシカ、ニホンザル、ニホンジカ、イノシシ、タヌキ、キツネ、アナグマ、ニホンノウサギなどといった中大型の哺乳類をはじめ、ヤマネ、ムササビといった小型の哺乳類も生息している。
sen.e: The mammals living there include small-sized ones, such as Japanese dormouse and flying squirrels, in addition to mid-sized/large-sized ones, such as black bears, Japanese serows, Japanese monkeys, Japanese sika deer, wild boars, raccoon dogs, red foxes, badgers, and Japanese hares.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The mammals living here include small ones, such as the Japanese dormouse and flying squirrels, in addition to mid to large animals, such as black bears, Japanese serows, Japanese monkeys, Japanese sika deer, wild boars, raccoon dogs, red foxes, badgers, and Japanese hares.

The mammals living here include small ones, such as the Japanese dormouse and flying squirrels, in addition to mid to large animals, such as black bears, Japanese serows, Japanese monkeys, Japanese sika deer, wild boars, raccoon dogs, red foxes, badgers, and Japanese hares.

sen.j: その中にはクロホオヒゲコウモリやミズラモグラなどの貴重な種も生存している。
sen.e: In particular, the mammals living there also include such precious species as Black whiskered bats and Japanese Mountain Mole.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In particular, mammals living there also include such precious species as Black whiskered bats and the Japanese Mountain Mole.
In particular, mammals living there also include such precious species as black whiskered bats and Japanese mountain moles.
sen.cmt: Black whiskered bats→black whiskered bats,the Japanese Mountain Mole→Japanese mountain moles

sen.j: 鳥類ではコノハズクやヤマセミ、オシドリなどをはじめオオタカやハイタカなどの猛禽類も見られる。
sen.e: Concerning birds, you can see there such predatory birds as goshawks and sparrow hawks, in addition to Japanese scops owls, Greater Pied Kingfishers and mandarin ducks.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: You can see there predatory birds as goshawks and sparrow hawks, in addition to Japanese scops owls, Greater Pied Kingfishers and mandarin ducks.
Regarding birds, there are screech owls, crested kingfisher and mandarin ducks, and raptors are also found such as goshawks and sparrow hawks.
sen.cmt: 原文より、全体的に修正しました。

sen.j: まれにイヌワシも見られる。
sen.e: In addition, golden eagles are seen there sometimes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, golden eagles are sometimes seen there.
Golden eagles are also seen there rarely
sen.cmt: In addition を削除し、also を付け足しました。

sen.j: 爬虫類ではニホンマムシやヤマカガシ、アオダイショウ、シマヘビ、ニホンカナヘビ、ニホンイシガメ、ジムグリ、シロマダラを見ることができる。
sen.e: Concerning reptiles, you can see there Japanese copperheads, Japanese grass snakes, Japanese rat snakes, Japanese striped rat snakes, Japanese grass lizard, Japanese pond turtle, burrowing rat snakes, and Oriental odd-tooth snakes.

For reptiles, one can find Japanese copperheads, Japanese grass snakes, Japanese rat snakes, Japanese striped rat snakes, Japanese grass lizard, Japanese pond turtle, burrowing rat snakes, and Oriental odd-tooth snakes.

For reptiles, one can find Japanese copperheads, Japanese grass snakes, Japanese rat snakes, Japanese striped rat snakes, Japanese grass lizard, Japanese pond turtle, burrowing rat snakes, and Oriental odd-tooth snakes.

sen.j: 両生類では特別天然記念物であるオオサンショウウオをはじめ、ハコネサンショウウオやヒダサンショウウオ、モリアオガエルやカジカガエルなどを見ることができる。
sen.e: Concerning amphibians, in addition to Japanese Giant Salamanders, which are a special natural treasure, you can see there Japanese Clawed Salamanders, forest green tree frogs and Japanese singing frogs
For amphibians, in addition to the Japanese Giant Salamanders, which is a special natural treasure, one can find Japanese Clawed Salamanders, forest green tree frogs and Japanese singing frogs

For amphibians, as well as the Japanese giant salamanders, which are a protected species, one can find Japanese clawed salamanders, Hida salamander, forest green tree frogs and Japanese singing frogs.
sen.cmt: Japanese Giant Salamanders→Japanese giant salamanders,special natural treasure→protected species,Japanese Clawed Salamanders→Japanese clawed salamander,Hida salamander を挿入しました。

sen.j: 昆虫もカブトムシやクワガタ、ミヤマカラスアゲハをはじめとした大型の個体から小型の個体まで、多く見られる種から貴重な種まで多種多様な昆虫が生息している。
sen.e: Concerning insects as well, in addition to Japanese dynastid beetles, stag beetles, and Alpine Black Swallowtail, a variety of insects, from large-sized ones to small-sized ones and from popular ones to precious ones, live there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For insects, in addition to the Japanese dynastid beetles, stag beetles, and Alpine Black Swallowtail, a variety of insects, from large ones to small ones, popular to precious ones, live here.
For insects, in addition to the Japanese rhinoceros beetles, stag beetles, and Alpine black swallowtail, a variety of insects, from large ones to small ones, popular to precious ones, live here.
sen.cmt: Japanese dynastid beetles→Japanese rhinoceros beetles,Alpine Black Swallowtail→Alpine black swallowtail

sen.j: 中には芦生で新たに記録された種もいくつか見られる。
sen.e: In particular, there are some species that were newly found in Ashiu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There are some species that were newly found in Ashiu.
There are some species that were newly found in Ashiu.

tit.j: 学術研究の場としての研究林
tit.e: The forest for research as a field for academic research
The forest for research as a field for academic research
The forest for research as a field for academic research

sen.j: 大学は当研究林の設立時に、事前調査等を通じて以下の3点に注目していた。
sen.e: When establishing this forest for research, the university paid attention to the following three points:
When establishing this forest for research, the university paid attention to the following three points:
When establishing this forest for research, the university paid attention to the following three points:

sen.j: スギの郷土の中心であること
sen.e: The place is located at the center of the Japanese cedar-growing area.
The place is located at the center of the Japanese cedar-growing area.
The place is located at the center of the Japanese cedar-growing area.

sen.j: 寒地性植物と暖地性植物が交わってともに自生する大植物園であること
sen.e: The place constitutes a large botanical garden where plants favoring cold areas and those favoring warm areas grow mixed naturally.
The place constitutes a large botanical garden where plants favoring cold areas and those favoring warm areas naturally grow together.
The place constitutes a large botanical garden where plants favoring cold climate and those favoring warm climate naturally grow together.

sen.j: 大きな流域実験の可能性を有する地形であること
sen.e: Its geographical shape provides the possibility that large-scale experiments will be conducted over river-including areas.
Its geographical shape provides the possibility that large-scale experiments can be conducted over river-including areas.
Its geographical shape provides the possibility that large-scale experiments can be conducted over river basin.

sen.j: 実際、西日本有数の原生林の中で現在までに確認された植物の種類は約900種を数え、その中には前述のアシウスギやアシウテンナンショウのように「芦生」の名を冠されたものもある。
sen.e: Actually, the number of plant species found in the virgin forest, one of the big ones in Western Japan, exceeds approx. 900, including Ashiu-sugi and Ashiu-tennansho named after Ashiu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Actually, the number of plant species found in the virgin forest, one of the big ones in Western Japan, exceeds approx. 900, including Ashiu-sugi and Ashiu-tennansho named after Ashiu.
Actually, the number of plant species found in the virgin forest, one of the major ones in Western Japan, is approx. 900, including Ashiu-sugi and Ashiu-tennansho as named after Ashiu.
sen.cmt: asを挿入して補強しました。exceeds→is

sen.j: この豊富な植物相の中から、「植物ヲ学ブモノハ一度ハ京大ノ芦生演習林ヲ見ルベシ」という、今に至るまで人口に膾炙する名言が生まれたといっていい。
sen.e: It can be said that, from such a diversity of its flora, the famous sentence of "The persons studying flora should once visit the Ashiu forest for field practice of Kyoto University," being widely known even today, was born.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It can be said that the famous quote "The persons studying flora should once visit the Ashiu forest for field practice of Kyoto University," was based on the diversity of its flora.
It can be said that the famous quote "The persons studying flora should once visit the Ashiu forest for field practice of Kyoto University," was based on the diversity of its flora.

sen.j: しかし、後述するように大学の研究施設でありながら財産形成の場として一定の利益を上げることを求められた。
sen.e: However, although the forest was a research facility of a university, it was requested to earn a certain amount of profit, to form wealth, as described later.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, although the forest was a research facility for the university, it was expected to derive a certain amount of profit, as described later.
However, as described later, although the forest was a research facility for the university, it was expected to derive a certain amount of profit as an income resource.
sen.cmt: ”財産形成の場として”: as an income resource として付け加えました。

sen.j: したがって、研究と利益確保の矛盾する命題を追う過程で、研究と施業の双方で妥協せざるを得ない場面に遭遇することもままあった。
sen.e: Therefore, in the processes of pursuing a contradicting theme that research had to be done and profits had to be gained as well, compromises had sometimes to be made both in the research and in the business.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Since there was a contradiction in pursuing both research and profit-driven business aspects, compromises had to be made both in research and in business.

Therefore, in the process of pursuing the contradictory themes that research had to be done and profits had to be gained as well, compromises had sometimes to be made both in the research and in the business.
sen.cmt: 原文から考えて、trans1より修正しました。

sen.j: もっとも、ツキノワグマが樹液を吸うためにスギの樹皮をはいで幹をかじるクマハギへの対策や人工林の育成及び収穫技術に関する研究などのように、伐採や植林といった施業の中で進められた研究も少なくない。
sen.e: However, not a few research projects, such as investigating measures against the bark-peeling of Japanese cedars by black bears that sucked the sap of these trees and developing the technologies to grow artificial forests and to get harvest from them, were conducted in the business of cutting woods and planting trees.

However, many research projects, such as investigating measures against the bark-peeling of Japanese cedars by black bears which sucked the sap of these trees as well as developing technologies to grow artificial forests and harvesting such forests, were conducted in the name of the business of logging and planting trees.

However, many research projects, such as investigating measures against the bark-peeling of Japanese cedars by black bears which sucked the sap of these trees as well as developing technologies to grow artificial forests and harvesting such forests, were conducted in the name of the business of logging and planting trees.

sen.j: こうした施業を通じた研究をはじめとした林業や林産業に関する研究のほか、農林の多目的利用と森林情報の処理に関する研究、森林の保全機能や天然林の再生機構といった森林のメカニズムに関するもの、研究林内に生息する動植物の生態や分類に関する研究、気泡や地形といった自然環境に関する研究など、多様な分野で当研究林をフィールドとした研究が行われている。
sen.e: In addition to researches concerning the forest industry, which included those conducted through doing business, researches in a variety of other fields are conducted as well using this forest for research as a field, as described in the following: researches concerning multi-purpose use of the forests utilized for agricultural purposes and concerning the processing of forest-related information, those concerning forest mechanisms, such as forest-maintaining functions and natural forest regeneration mechanisms, those concerning the ecology and classification of the flora and fauna that live in the forest for research, and those concerning natural environments, such as air bubbles and geographical shapes.

In addition to research concerning the forest industry, which included those conducted through doing business, research in a variety of other fields was conducted as well using the research forest for field research: research concerning the multi-purpose use of the forests utilized for agricultural purposes and concerning the processing of forest-related information, those concerning forest mechanisms, such as forest-maintaining functions and natural forest regeneration mechanisms, those concerning the ecology and classification of the flora and fauna that live in the research forest, and those concerning natural environments, such as air bubbles and geographical shapes.

In addition to research concerning forestry and forest industry, which included those conducted through doing business, research in a variety of other fields was conducted as well using the research forest for field research: research concerning the multi-purpose use of the forests utilized for agricultural purposes and concerning the processing of forest-related information, those concerning forest mechanisms, such as forest-maintaining functions and natural forest regeneration mechanisms, those concerning the ecology and classification of the flora and fauna that live in the research forest, and those concerning natural environments, such as air bubbles and geographical shapes.
sen.cmt: 林業や林産業; forestry and forest industry としました。

sen.j: 教育の場としての研究林では、農学部、農学研究科をはじめとした京都大学の各学部及び研究科の実習や教育プログラムの場として使用されている
sen.e: For educational purposes, this forest for research is used for field works and education programs in each department or graduate course of Kyoto University in addition to the agricultural department and its graduate course.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For educational purposes, this research forest is used for field work and educational programs in each department or graduate courses for Kyoto University in addition to the agricultural department and its graduate course.

For educational purposes, this research forest is used for field work and educational programs in each faculty or graduate courses for Kyoto University in addition to Faculty of Agriculture and Graduate School of Agriculture.
sen.cmt: department→faculty 農学部、農学研究科の名称を修正しました。

sen.j: ほか、京都造形芸術大学や同志社大学など他大学の実習や社会教育の場として使用されている。
sen.e: Furthermore, the forest is also used for field work or social education by other universities, such as Kyoto University of Art and Design and Doshisha University.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, the forest is also used for field work or social education by other universities, such as the Kyoto University of Art and Design and Doshisha University.
Furthermore, the forest is also used for field work or social education by other universities, such as Kyoto University of Art and Design and Doshisha University.

sen.j: 当研究林には後述のとおり由良川源流沿いに森林軌道が設置されている。
sen.e: As described later, a forest tramroad is laid out in this forest for research.
As described later, there is a forest tramroad in this research forest.
As described later, there is a forest tramline in this research forest.

sen.j: 日本の大学研究林(演習林)で森林鉄道が設置されたのは、奥秩父の山中にある東京大学秩父演習林内に設置された東京大学演習林軌道の他に例を見ない。
sen.e: Only other forest tramroad laid out in a forest for research (forest for field practice) of a university in Japan is the forest-for-field-practice tranmroad of Tokyo University that is laid out in the Chichibu forest for field practice of Tokyo University, located in the Oku-Chichibu mountain area.

The only other forest tramroad laid out in a research forest (forest for field practice) for a university in Japan is the forest-for-field-practice tranmroad for Tokyo University that is laid out in Tokyo University's Chichibu field practice forest, located in the Oku-Chichibu mountain area.

The only other forest tramline laid out in a research forest (forest for field practice) for a university in Japan is the forest-for-field-practice tranmline for Tokyo University that is laid out in Tokyo University's Chichibu field practice forest, located in the Oku-Chichibu mountain area.

sen.j: 演習林開設以前、この地域には道らしい道が整備されていなかった。
sen.e: Before the forest for field practice was established, no road that could be called a road existed in this area.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Before the field practice forest was established, there were no roads that could be called roads in the area.
Before the field practice forest was established, there were no roads that could be called roads in the area.

sen.j: したがって、演習林の開設と同時に林道の整備を開始した。
sen.e: Therefore, immediately after the forest for field practice was established, the work to provide forest roads started.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, immediately after the field practice forest was established, work was started to provide roads within the forests.
Therefore, immediately after the field practice forest was established, work was started to provide forest roads.

sen.j: 主要な林道はなるべく自動車の通行が可能なように整備された。
sen.e: Major roads were provided so that vehicles could run on them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Major roads were provided so that vehicles could run on them.
Major forest roads were provided so that cars could run on them.

sen.j: しかし、やむをえない場所については軌道で整備されることとなり、演習林事務所から由良川源流に沿って中山に至る区間に軌道を敷設することが計画された。
sen.e: However, it was decided that tramroads would be laid out in the areas where no other means would be available, and it was planned to lay out tramroads in the portion that started at the administration building of the forest for field practice and reached Nakayama along the river flow in the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa river.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it was decided that tramroads would be laid out in areas where no other means would be available, tramraods were planned to be layed out that started from the field practice forest administration building and reach to Nakayama along the river flow in the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa river.

However, it was decided that tramlines would be laid out in areas where no other means would be available, tramlines were planned to be laid out that started from the field practice forest administration building and reach to Nakayama along the river flow in the headwaters area of the Yura-gawa River.

sen.j: 工事は1927年に事務所から大蓬までの軌道敷開削工事が完成、翌1928年には七瀬まで完成した。
sen.e: The work to cut and make flat land for laying out a tramroad was completed up to Oyomogi in 1927 and up to Nanase in 1928.
The work to cut and make flat land for laying out the tramroad was completed up to Oyomogi in 1927 and to Nanase in 1928.
The excavation work to lay out the tramline form the administration building to Oyomogi was completed in 1927, and to Nanase in the following year 1928.
sen.cmt: tramroad→tramline 全体的に修正しました。

sen.j: 当初完成したのは路盤だけであった。
sen.e: Only the roadbeds were completed initially.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Only the roadbeds were completed initially.
Only the roadbeds were completed initially.

sen.j: しかし、軌道の敷設工事も行われ、1934年には事務所～赤崎間にレールを敷設、1936年には大蓬まで延伸された。
sen.e: However, the work to lay out tramroads was also conducted, the rails between the administration building and Akazaki laid out in 1934 and extended up to Oyomogi in 1936.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, work to lay out tramroads was also conducted, and the rails between the administration building and Akazaki were laid out in 1934 and extended up to Oyomogi in 1936.
However, the work to lay out tramlines was also conducted, and the rails between the administration building and Akazaki were laid out in 1934 and extended up to Oyomogi in 1936.

sen.j: 敷設された軌道の軌間は762mmで、レールの重さは6kgないし4kg、枕木は伐採された栗材やブナ材に腐食防止用のクレオソート油を塗ったものを使用した。
sen.e: The track gauge of the tramroads was 762 mm, the weight of a rail 6 kg or 4 kg, and the cut chestnut trees or cut beech trees on which creosote oil was pasted for protection against corrosion were used for the railroad ties.

The track gauge of the tramroads was 762 mm, the weight of a rail 6 kg or 4 kg, while cut chestnut trees or cut beech trees on which creosote oil was pasted for protection against corrosion were used for railroad ties.

The track gauge of the tramlines was 762 mm, the weight of a rail was 6 kg or 4 kg, cut chestnut trees or cut beech trees were used as railroad ties, which had creosote oil pasted on to protect against rot.
sen.cmt: tramroads→tramlines 腐食:corrosionとありますが、この場合”木”であることからrotとしました。

sen.j: しかし、当初計画区間のうち七瀬～中山間については路盤工事も行われず、歩道として整備されるにとどまった。
sen.e: However, for the initially-planned section between Nanase and Nakayama, even the work to provide rail beds was not conducted, with only walking roads provided there.
However, even the work to provide rail beds was not conducted for the initially-planned section between Nanase and Nakayama, with only walking roads provided there.
However, even the work to provide rail beds was not conducted for the initially-planned section between Nanase and Nakayama, with only walking roads provided there.

sen.j: その後、太平洋戦争が始まると林産資源確保のために小野子谷への軌道延伸が計画された。
sen.e: When the Pacific War started after that, it was planned to extend the tramroad up to Onokodani to secure resources for the forest industry.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the Pacific War started, the tramroad was to be extended up to Onokodani to secure resources for the forest industry.
After the Pacific War started, the tramline was planned to be extended up to Onokodani to secure the forest resource.
sen.cmt: tramroad→tramline 林産資源: forest resourceとし、修正しました。plannedを挿入しました。

sen.j: 1942年に由良川を渡る橋が完成、1943年には小野子東谷にあった作業所まで軌道の延伸が行われた。
sen.e: The construction of a bridge to cross the Yura-gawa river was completed in 1942, and the tramroad was extended in 1943 up to a work site located in Onokodani.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The construction of a bridge to cross the Yura-gawa river was completed in 1942, and the tramroad was extended in 1943 up to a work site located in Onokodani.
The construction of a bridge to cross the Yura-gawa River was completed in 1942, and the tramline was extended in 1943 up to a work site located in Onokodani.

sen.j: 七瀬までの本線区間が本谷軌道と呼ばれたのに対して小野子仮軌道と名づけられた。
sen.e: While the main section of up to Nanase was called the Honkoku (literally, real valley) tramroad, the new section was named the Onoko provisional tramroad.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処本谷軌道： 読み方確認できておりません。
sen.e: While the main section up to Nanase was called the Honkoku (literally, real valley) tramroad, the new section was named the Onoko provisional tramroad.
While the main section up to Nanase was called the Honkoku (literally, real valley) tramline, the new section was named the Onoko provisional tramline.
sen.cmt: 本谷軌道:読み方は確認できていませんが、「美山町知見本谷（ミヤマチョウチミホンタニ）」という場所があります。tramroad→tramline

sen.j: 1944年には小野子仮軌道の途中から分離して小野子西谷を遡上する区間が延伸された。
sen.e: In 1944, the Onoko provisional tramroad was branched at some point on it, and a section rising along Onoko Nishidani (Onoko west ravine) was extended from the point.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1944, at some point it branched off the Onoko provisional tramroad, and a section rising along Onoko Nishidani (Onoko west ravine) was extended from this point.
In 1944, a section was extended from the middle of Onoko provisional tramline to rise along Onoko Nishidani (Onoko west ravine).

sen.j: しかし、この区間は仮軌道とは言いながらも線路を内務省 (日本)の由良川堰堤工事事務所から借用したものを使用するなど、路盤も線路も本谷軌道より高規格のものが使用された。
sen.e: However, although the section was specified as a provisional tramroad, the grades of the roadbeds and rails used there were higher than those used for the Honkoku tramroad: For example, the rails used there were borrowed from the Yuragawa-river dam construction office of Ministry of Interior (in Japan).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, although the section was specified as a provisional tramroad, the grades of the roadbeds and rails used there were higher than those used for the Honkoku tramroad: For example, the rails used there were borrowed from the Yuragawa-river dam construction office of Ministry of Interior (in Japan).

However, although the section was specified as a provisional tramline, the grades of the roadbeds and rails used there were higher than those used for the Honkoku tramline, as the rails used there were borrowed from the Yuragawa-river dam construction office of Ministry of Interior (in Japan).
sen.cmt: tramroad→tramline :For example,をas,に修正しました。

sen.j: また、小野子仮軌道にはループ線があったという話が残っている。
sen.e: It is said that a looped section was provided on the Onoko provisional tramroad.
It is said that a looped section was provided on the Onoko provisional tramroad.
It is said that a looped section was provided on the Onoko provisional tramline.

sen.j: 完成した軌道は伐採された材木や製造された木炭、栽培されたしいたけの搬出に使用されたほか、沿線に設けられた作業所や苗畑への通勤や資材の搬入にも使用された。
sen.e: The completed tramroads were used not only for carrying out cut woods, manufactured charcoal and cultivated shiitake mushrooms, but also for commuting to the work sites and young plant fields provided along the tramroads and for carrying in materials.

The completed tramroads were used not only to transport logged wood, manufactured charcoal or cultivated shiitake mushrooms, but also by people for commuting to the work sites and young plant fields provided along the tramroads and for bringing in materials.

The completed tramlines were used not only to transport logged wood, manufactured charcoal or cultivated shiitake mushrooms, but also by people for commuting to the work sites and fields for seedlings provided along the tramlines and for bringing in materials.
sen.cmt: young plant fields→fields for seedlings tramroads→tramlines

sen.j: また、灰野の住民への米やみそ・しょうゆといった生活物資の運搬にも使用された。
sen.e: In addition, the tramroads were also used for conveying everyday commodities, such as rice, miso (soybean paste) and soy sauce, to residents in Haino.
In addition, the tramroads also used to convey everyday commodities, such as rice, miso (soybean paste) and soy sauce, to residents in Haino.
In addition, the tramlines were also used to convey everyday commodities, such as rice, miso (soybean paste) and soy sauce, to the residents in Haino.
sen.cmt: wereを挿入しました。tramroads→tramlines theを挿入しました。

sen.j: 小野子仮軌道からは主としてブナ材が搬出され、多くがプロペラのブレード(羽根)に加工された。
sen.e: Using the Onoko provisional tramroad, beech wood was mainly carried out to be used mostly for the blades of propellers.
Beech wood was mainly carried out using the Onoko provisional tramroad, for use in making the blades of propellers.
Beech wood was mainly carried out using the Onoko provisional tramline, for use in making the blades of propellers.

sen.j: 戦後の1947年には小野子西軌道が撤去され、レールは元通りの直線に延ばされて内務省由良川堰堤工事事務所に返却された。
sen.e: In 1947 after the war, the Onoko Nishi (west) tramroad was removed, and the rails were made straight as in the original form and were returned to the Yuragawa-river dam construction office of Ministry of Interior.

In 1947 after the war, the Onoko Nishi (west) tramroad was removed, and the rails were returned to their original straight form and given back to the Yuragawa-river dam construction office of Ministry of Interior.

In 1947 after the war, the Onoko Nishi (west) tramline was removed, and the rails were returned to their original straight form and given back to the Yuragawa-river dam construction office of Ministry of Interior.

sen.j: 1949年7月に来襲したへスター台風によって、森林軌道を全線に渡って大きな被害を受けた。
sen.e: The forest tramroads were heavily damaged over the entire lines by Typhoon Hester that hit the area in July of 1949.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The forest tramroads were heavily damaged by Typhoon Hester that hit the area in July of 1949.
The forest tramlines were heavily damaged by Typhoon Hester that hit the area in July 1949.
sen.cmt: tramroads→tramlines of を削除しました。

sen.j: 中でも小野子仮軌道は全区間埋没・流出して、その後復旧することはなかった。
sen.e: In particular, the Onoko provisional tramroad were buried or flown out all over its entire sections, being never restored again.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In particular, entire sections of the Onoko provisional tramroad were buried or destroyed, never to be restored again.
In particular, entire sections of the Onoko provisional tramline were buried or washed out, never to be restored again.
sen.cmt: tramroad→tramline, ”流出”:were destroyed→were washed out として修正しました。

sen.j: 一方、本谷軌道については流出した由良川橋梁の復旧が行われたほか、1950年には軌道の敷設区間が野田谷まで延伸された。
sen.e: On the other hand, concerning the honkoku tramraod, the bridge over the Yura-gawa river that had been flown out was restored, and furthermore, the tramroad was extended up to Nodatani in 1950.
On the other hand, concerning the honkoku tramraod, the bridge over the Yura-gawa river that had been destroyed was restored, and furthermore, the tramroad was extended up to Nodatani in 1950.
On the other hand, regarding the Honkoku tramline, the bridge over the Yura-gawa River that had been washed out was restored, and furthermore, the tramline was extended up to Nodatani in 1950.
sen.cmt: 全体的に修正しました。

sen.j: 先に路盤が完成していた七瀬まであと少しの距離であったが、ついに七瀬までレールが延びることはなかった。
sen.e: The tramroad remained not constructed for a little distance up to Nanase up to where roadbeds had been completed, but the tramroad has never been extended up to Nanase.
The tramroad remained unfinished for a little distance up to Nanase where roadbeds had been completed, but the tramroad has never been extended up to Nanase.
The tramline remained unfinished for a little distance up to Nanase where roadbeds had been completed, but the tramline has never been extended up to Nanase.

sen.j: 1950年代以降の大規模伐採の時代には、赤崎西谷や赤崎東谷に引込み線が設けられ、伐採された材木の搬出に活用されていた。
sen.e: In the era after 1950s when woods were cut on a large scale, sidings to Akazaki-nishidani (Akazaki west ravine) and to Akazaki-higashidani (Akazaki east ravine) were laid out and were used effectively for carrying out cut woods.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the 1950s when logging was carried out on a large scale, sidings were laid out in Akazaki-nishidani (Akazaki west ravine) up to Akazaki-higashidani (Akazaki east ravine) and were used for effective logging.

After the 1950s when logging was carried out on a large scale, sidings were laid out in Akazaki-nishidani (Akazaki west ravine) up to Akazaki-higashidani (Akazaki east ravine) and were used for carrying out the lumber.
sen.cmt: ”材木の搬出”部分を修正しました。

sen.j: 1960年代中期に沿線での伐採事業が終了すると森林軌道の利用価値は低下した。
sen.e: However, after the wood-cutting business was terminated in mid-1960s, the use value of the forest tramroads diminished.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, after the logging business was terminated in mid-1960s, the value of the forest tramroads diminished.
However, after the logging business was terminated in mid-1960s, the value of the usage of the forest tramlines diminished.

sen.j: それ以後、沿線の苗畑や作業所への通勤や資材、苗の搬入に使われる程度となった。
sen.e: Since then, they were used only for commuting to the fields for young plants and work sites provided along the line and for carrying in materials and young plants.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Since then, they were used only to commute to the fields for young plants and work sites provided along the line and for carrying in materials and young plants.
Since then, they were used only to commute to the fields for seedlings and work sites provided along the line and for carrying in materials and seedlings.

sen.j: それも1975年前後に終了すると、使用頻度が更に低下した。
sen.e: After such a way of using the tramroads was also terminated in around 1975, the use frequency of them diminished further.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the tramroads were terminated around 1975, their use was even further diminished.
Then, when that was finished around 1975, the use of the tramlines was even further diminished.
sen.cmt: tramroads→tramlines,原文から全文との関連を考えて修正しました。

sen.j: 1980年代以降になると施設の老朽化が進んだことから、灰野より奥へ運転されることはなくなった。
sen.e: After 1980s, the facility became increasingly more degraded, and no operation over Haino became to be conducted.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the 1980s, the facility became increasingly degraded, and no operation over Haino came to be conducted.
After the 1980s, the facility became increasingly degraded, and no operation beyond Haino came to be conducted.

sen.j: 一方、残された灰野までの区間については、この区間に道路がないことから、今後も軌道を使用する必要があった。
sen.e: On the other hand, no road was provided for the remaining section up to Haino, and it was necessary to use the tramroad even thereafter.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the other hand, no road was provided for the remaining section up to Haino, and the tramroad had to be used thereafter.
On the other hand, no road was provided for the remaining section up to Haino, and the tramline had to be used thereafter.

sen.j: そのため、1973年にたびたび水害で流されてきた由良川橋梁を鉄筋コンクリート製の橋に架け替えたほか、枕木を一部コンクリート製のものにするなど軌道の整備が行われた。
sen.e: Therefore, the Yura-gawa river bridge that had been flown out many times was replaced with a reinforced concrete one in 1973 and the tramroads were improved, for example, by replacing some of the tramroad ties with those of concrete.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the Yura-gawa river bridge that had been destroyed many times was replaced with a reinforced concrete one in 1973 and the tramroads were improved, for example, by replacing some of the tramroad ties with those of concrete.

Therefore, the Yura-gawa River bridge that had been destroyed many times was replaced with a reinforced concrete one in 1973 and the tramroads were improved, for example, by replacing some of the tramroad ties with those of concrete.

sen.j: 整備区間は年々奥へと延伸された。
sen.e: The improved sections were extended more and more remotely.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The improved sections were extended to more and more remote areas.
The improved sections were extended to more and more remote areas.

sen.j: 1993年には灰野橋が鋼鉄製の桁橋に架け替えられたことにより、整備区間が灰野の先まで延伸された。
sen.e: In 1993, the Haino bridge was replaced with a steel girder one, and therefore, the sections whose the facilities were to be improved were extended over Haino.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1993, the Haino bridge was replaced with a steel girder and therefore, the sections whose facilities were to be improved were extended over Haino.
In 1993, the Haino-bashi Bridge was replaced with a steel girder and therefore, the sections whose facilities were to be improved were extended over Haino.

sen.j: 最近では由良川橋梁に、歩行者の転落防止のために手すりが取り付けられている。
sen.e: Recently, hand rails have been provided for the Yura-gawa river bridge to prevent pedestrians from falling out of there.
Recently, hand rails have been provided for the Yura-gawa river bridge to prevent pedestrians from falling.
Recently, hand rails have been provided for the Yura-gawa River bridge to prevent pedestrians from falling.

sen.j: 車両は東京大学演習林軌道が大規模な伐採事業を行っていたことから本格的なガソリン機関車やディーゼル機関車を所有していた。
sen.e: Concerning the tramcars, the Tokyo University tramroad for the forest for field practice owned full-fledged gasoline locomotives and diesel locomotives because the university conducted wood-cutting business on a large scale.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Concerning the tramcars, the Tokyo University tramroad for the field practice forest owned full-fledged gasoline locomotives and diesel locomotives because the university conducted logging business on a large scale.

Concerning the tramcars, the Tokyo University tramline for the field practice forest owned full-fledged gasoline locomotives and diesel locomotives because the university conducted logging business on a large scale.

sen.j: それに対して当研究林では、当初、トロッコを人力や馬力で押し上げ、下りはブレーキを操作しつつ滑走していた。
sen.e: For this, in this forest for research, man-power or horse-power was used initially for pushing up tramcars, and on down-slopes, they slid by themselves, controlled with a brake.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In this research forest, man-power or horse-power was used initially to push tramcars, and on down-slopes, they slid by themselves, controlled by a brake.
In this research forest, man-power or horse-power was used initially to push tramcars, and on down-slopes, they slid by themselves, controlled by a brake.

sen.j: その後機関車を導入して作業の効率化を図った。
sen.e: After that, locomotives were introduced to make the work done more efficiently.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After that, locomotives were introduced to increase the effeciency of work.
After that, locomotives were introduced to increase the efficiency of work.

sen.j: しかし、機関車といってもトロッコの台枠に農業用のエンジンを搭載し、その上に簡単な屋根を乗せただけのものだったので、屋台形機関車と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: However, they were simply made, with an engine for agricultural use being set on the bed of a tramcar and a simple roof placed over it, and were called stall-type locomotives.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, they were simply made, with an engine for agricultural use, set on the bed of a tramcar and a simple roof placed over it, and were called stall-type locomotives.
However, they were simply made, with an engine for agricultural use, set on the bed of a tramcar and a simple roof placed over it, and were called stall-type locomotives.

sen.j: 機関車以外にもトロッコの台枠にダイハツ・ミゼットのエンジンを搭載した自走式人車もあり、こちらは林内の巡視などに使用されていた。
sen.e: In addition to locomotives, self-propelled cars for human beings, with an engine for Daihatsu Midget, were also provided and were used for making a tour of inspection within the forest.
In addition to locomotives, self-propelled cars for people, using an engine for the Daihatsu Midget, were also provided and used to make inspection tours within the forest.
In addition to locomotives, self-propelled vehicles for people, using an engine of the Daihatsu Midget, were also provided and used to make inspection tours within the forest.
sen.cmt: self-propelled cars→self propelled vehicles,for→ofと修正しました。

sen.j: また、大規模伐採時期には業者が機関車やトロッコを持ち込んで使用していたが、こちらの実態については不明である。
sen.e: When the wood-cutting business was conducted on a large scale, the business operators brought in their own locomotives and/or tramcars, but their details are not known.
When the logging business was conducted on a large scale, the business operators brought in their own locomotives and/or tramcars, but the details are not known.
When the logging business was conducted on a large scale, the business operators brought in their own locomotives and/or tramcars, but the details are not known.

sen.j: 現在の森林軌道は林内の巡視などのために灰野までの区間で極めて不定期ながら運行されている。
sen.e: The present forest tramroad is operated irregularly, for example, for making a tour of inspection in the sections up to Haino.
The present forest tramroad is still in operation although infrequently, and used to carry out inspection tours in areas up to Haino as well as other work.
The present forest tramline is still in operation although infrequently, and used to carry out inspection tours in areas up to Haino as well as other work.

sen.j: 灰野から先は落石や倒木、あるいは赤崎の大Ωループ橋のように朽ち果てて倒壊した木橋などが連続しており、軌道の復活はおろか歩行も困難を要する。
sen.e: In the remote areas over Haino, there are fallen stones, fallen trees, or rotten and collapsed tree bridges like the big Ω loop bridge at Akazaki in succession, and it is difficult even to walk there, to say nothing of restoring the tramroard.

In the remote areas over Haino, there are fallen stones, fallen trees, or rotten and collapsed tree bridges like the big Ω loop bridge at Akazaki in succession, and it is difficult to walk there, to say nothing of restoring the tramroard.

In the remote areas beyond Haino, there are fallen stones, fallen trees, or rotten and collapsed tree bridges like the big Ω loop bridge at Akazaki one after another, and it is difficult to walk there, to say nothing of restoring the tramroard.

sen.j: また、国土地理院の1/25,000地形図「中」では1979年修正、1981年5月発行版まで「特殊軌道」の記号で表されていたものが、1991年修正、1992年5月発行版では「徒歩道」の記号で表されている。
sen.e: On the "Middle"1/25,000 topographical maps published by Geographical Survey Institute, a "special tramroad" mark was placed at the location in the version that was corrected in 1979 and was published in May, 1985 and in the earlier versions, but a "pedestrian road" mark is placed there in the version that was corrected in 1991 and was published in May, 1992.

On the "Middle"1/25,000 topographical maps published by Geographical Survey Institute, a "special tramroad" mark was placed at the location in the version that was corrected in 1979 and was published in May, 1985 and in the earlier versions, but a "pedestrian road" mark is placed there in the version that was corrected in 1991 and was published in May, 1992.

Also, on the "Middle" 1/25,000 topographical maps published by Geographical Survey Institute, modified in 1979, the symbol shown on it as "special tramline" until the version published in May 1981 was modified in 1991, then on the version published in May 1992, it is shown as the symbol of "footpath".

sen.j: この項では当研究林が発足するまで(第1期)、演習林発足から昭和戦前期まで(第2期)、昭和戦後(1970年代まで)期(第3期)、それ以降現在に至る歴史(第4期)に分けて紹介する。
sen.e: In this chapter, its history is divided into the following four periods and description are made for each of them: the first period (until this forest for research was inaugurated), the second period (from the inauguration of the forest for field practice to the end of the Showa war), the third period (from the end of the Showa war to 1970s) and the fourth period (up to now after then).

In this chapter, its history is divided into the following four periods and descriptions are made for each of them: the first period (until this research forest was inaugurated), the second period (from the inauguration of the field practice forest to the end of the Showa war), the third period (from the end of the Showa war to 1970s) and the fourth period (up to now after then).

In this chapter, its history is divided into the following four periods and descriptions are made for each of them: the first period (until this research forest was inaugurated), the second period (from the inauguration of the field practice forest to the prewar in Showa era), the third period (from the postwar in Showa era up to 1970s) and the fourth period (up to now after then).
sen.cmt: ”昭和戦前、昭和戦後”等、修正しました。

sen.j: 当研究林のエリアも含めた旧北桑田郡及び隣接する旧葛野郡・愛宕郡両郡北部の山林地域は、平安京遷都以降内裏の造営をはじめとした建築用材確保のための杣山として指定されるなど、旺盛な京都の材木需要に支えられて伐採～更新のサイクルが繰り返されていた。
sen.e: In the mountain areas that include former Kitakuwada County, including the area of this forest for research, and also the northern part of both of former Kadono County and Otagi County bordering former Kitakuwada County, the cycle of forest-cutting and forest regeneration was repeated by being supported by active demand for woods in Kyoto: For example, the area was specified as a somayama (timber forest) to secure wood materials for constructing the dairi (Imperial Palace) and other buildings after the nation capital moved to Heian.

In the mountain areas that include former Kitakuwada County, including the area of this research forest, and also the northern part of both of former Kadono County and Otagi County bordering former Kitakuwada County, the cycle of logging and forest regeneration was repeated due to the active demand for wood in Kyoto: For example, the area was specified as a somayama (timber forest) to secure wood for constructing the dairi (Imperial Palace) and other buildings after the nation capital moved to Heian.

In the mountain areas that include former Kitakuwada County, including the area of this research forest, and also the northern forest part of both of former Kadono County and Otagi County bordering former Kitakuwada County, the cycle of logging and forest regeneration was repeated due to the active demand for wood in Kyoto as the area was specified as a somayama (timber forest) to secure wood for constructing the dairi (Imperial Palace) and other buildings after the relocation of the capital to Heian-kyo.
sen.cmt: ”北部の山林地域”という部分を修正しました。nation capital moved to Heia→relocation of the capital to Heian-kyo

sen.j: もっとも、当研究林のエリアは由良川源流の最深部であった。
sen.e: However, the area where this forest for research is located is placed in the most remote part of the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa river.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the area where this forest for research is located is placed in the most remote part of the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa river.
However, the area where this forest for research located was in the most remote part of the headwaters area of the Yura-gawa River.

sen.j: したがって、大消費地である京都市内に搬出するには筏流しで由良川を下っても、途中で一度峠越えをして大堰川（桂川 (淀川水系)）水系に搬出して京都市内に輸送する必要があった。
sen.e: Therefore, to carry out woods to the Kyoto City area where lots of woods were used, rafts made of them had to be flown down the Yura-gawa river but had to get over a pass before reaching the Oi-gawa River (the Katsura-gawa River (the Yodo-gawa River water system) water system and being carried out to the Kyoto City area.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, rafts made of wood, used to carry out wood to the Kyoto City area where copious amounts of wood was being used, had to be sent down the Yura-gawa river and over a pass before reaching the Oi-gawa River (the Katsura-gawa River (the Yodo-gawa River water system) water system and being carried out to Kyoto City area.

Therefore, even rafting down Yura-gawa River to carry out the wood to the mass-consumption area of Kyoto, still needed to go over a pass once before reaching the Oi-gawa River (the Katsura-gawa River:the Yodo-gawa River water system) water system to transport it to inner Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: Yura-gawa river→Yura-gawa River, 原文から考えて全体的に修正しました。

sen.j: このような大規模需要のほかにも由良川流域の福知山市、綾部市、あるいは山を越えた小浜市といった城下町における建築用材としての需要もあった
sen.e: In addition to such a demand for lots of woods, there also was demand for woods for constructing buildings in such castle-centered towns as Fukuchiyama City and Ayabe City located along the Yura-gawa River and Obama City on the other side of the mountain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Additionally there was also a demand for wood to be used in constructing buildings castle-centered towns such as Fukuchiyama City and Ayabe City which were located along the Yura-gawa River and Obama City on the other side of the mountain.

As well as this mass-consumption, there was also a demand for wood to be used in constructing buildings castle-centered towns such as Fukuchiyama City and Ayabe City which were located along the Yura-gawa River and Obama City on the other side of the mountain.
sen.cmt: ”このような大規模需要のほかにも”という点を付け足しました。

sen.j: ほか、地元の用材や木工品の材料、木炭製造に関する需要もあった。
sen.e: Furthermore, there was also local demand for constructing buildings, for woodworks and for making charcoal.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, there was also a local demand for constructing buildings, woodworks and making charcoal.
Furthermore, there were also local demands for wood for construction, materials for woodworks or for making charcoals.
sen.cmt: 原文から考えて修正しました。

sen.j: こうしたことから、古くから材木の伐採や炭焼きに従事するために、山中には源流域の谷筋を中心に後の知井村を構成する九つの字から移住した山番が住みついていた。
sen.e: In such situations, to engage in cutting woods or making charcoal, mountain guardians who moved from valleys in the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa River or nine small communities, which constituted Chii-mura Village later, came to live in the mountain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In such situations, mountain guardians who moved from valleys in the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa River or nine small communities, which constituted Chii-mura Village later, came to live in the mountain to engage in logging or making charcoal,

In such situations, mountain guardians who moved from nine small communities in the valleys around the headwaters of the Yura-gawa River which formed Chii-mura Village later, came to live in the mountain to engage in logging or making charcoal,
sen.cmt: riverhead→headwatersconstituted→formed原文から考えて修正しました。

sen.j: ほか、用材を求めて山中を移動する木地師が住みついており、木椀や盆などの木材加工品を製造していた。
sen.e: In addition, kijishi (wood masters) who moved within the mountains seeking for wood materials also came to live there, making wooden craft works, such as wooden bowls and trays.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, kijishi (wood masters) who moved within the mountains seeking wood also came to live there, making wooden craft works, such as wooden bowls and trays.
In addition, kijishi (wood masters) who moved within the mountains seeking wood also came to live there, making wooden craft works, such as wooden bowls and trays.

sen.j: こうした山林利用の他にも、佐々里峠から灰野に出て、一度由良川源流を下り、現在の事務所付近から櫃倉谷を通って権蔵坂で若狭に抜ける街道もあった。
sen.e: In addition to use of the mountain forests, there was also a road that went to Haino via Sasari-toge Mountain Pass, descended once along the riverhead area of the Yura-gawa River, passed Hitsukuradani from around the area where the present administration building is now located, reached Gonzozaka, and then went to Wakasa.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

In addition ton the use of mountain forests, there was also a road that went to Haino via Sasari-toge Mountain Pass, that descended once along the headwaters area of the Yura-gawa River, passed Hitsukuradani from around the area where the present administration building is now located, reached Gonzozaka, and then went to Wakasa.

sen.j: したがって、京都と小浜を結ぶサブルートとしての役割を果たしていた。
sen.e: Therefoore, this road played the role of a sub-road connecting Kyoto and Obama.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefoore, this road acted as a sub-road connecting Kyoto and Obama.
